rule.name: Template for custom Custom rules
rule.description:
Follow these steps to make your custom Custom rules available in SonarQube:

    1. Create a new rule in SonarQube by "copying" this rule template and specify the CheckId of your custom rule, a title, a description, and a default severity.
    2. Enable the newly created rule in your quality profile
  1. Relaunch an analysis on your projects, et voil√†, your custom rules are executed!

rule.name: Invalid free
rule.description: Calling free with the given address is illegal. This usually means that the block is already freed or that the block has never been allocated on the heap.

rule.name: Mismatched free() / delete / delete []
rule.description: Wrong deallocation function used to deallocate an allocated block. C++ rules are: - deallocate with 'free' when allocated with 'malloc', 'calloc', 'realloc', 'valloc' or 'memalign' - deallocate with 'delete' when allocated with 'new' - deallocate with 'delete []' when allocated with 'new []'

rule.name: Invalid read
rule.description: This happens when your program reads memory at a place which Memcheck reckons it shouldn't. The reasons include reading memory which isn't mapped, reading already freed memory etc.

rule.name: Invalid write
rule.description: This happens when your program writes memory at a place which Memcheck reckons it shouldn't. The reasons include writing to memory which isn't mapped, writing to already freed memory, writing to read-only memory etc.

rule.name: Invalid jump or move
rule.description: The program tried to jump or move to an invalid address.

rule.name: Overlap of source and destination memory blocks
rule.description: The following C library functions copy some data from one memory block to another (or something similar): memcpy, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat. The blocks pointed to by their 'src' and 'dst' pointers aren't allowed to overlap.

rule.name: Invalid memory pool
rule.description: Invalid memory pool specified in client request.

rule.name: Condition depends on undefined value
rule.description: Programs behavior relies on a variable whose value is not initialized, i.e. the program has undefined behavior.

rule.name: Use of undefined value
rule.description: Other uses of undefined values (primarily memory addresses).

rule.name: Invalid system call parameter
rule.description: A system call has been passed an 'out' or 'in' buffer which either isn't fully addressable or hasn't been properly initialized.

rule.name: Error in client request
rule.description: "Error" resulting from a client check request.

rule.name: Memory leak (definitely lost)
rule.description: Memory block which was unfreed at programs exit and for which no pointer pointing at it could be found. Such blocks are classified as "lost", because the programmer could not possibly have freed it at program exit, since no pointer to it exists. This is likely a symptom of having lost the pointer at some earlier point in the program. Such cases should be fixed by the programmer.

rule.name: Memory leak (indirectly lost)
rule.description: This means that the block is lost, not because there are no pointers to it, but rather because all the blocks that point to it are themselves lost. For example, if you have a binary tree and the root node is lost, all its children nodes will be indirectly lost.

rule.name: Memory leak (possibly lost)
rule.description: This means that a chain of one or more pointers to a block has been found, but at least one of the pointers is an interior-pointer. This could just be a random value in memory that happens to point into a block, and so you shouldn't consider this OK unless you know you have interior-pointers.

rule.name: Memory leak (still reachable)
rule.description: Blocks of memory which weren't lost (pointers pointing to them existed) but also weren't freed at process' exit. Since the block are pointed at, the programmer could, at least in principle, have freed it before the exit.
